Travel_History_Narrative.History of Travel Narrative: Patient reports recent travel within the past month, which may be relevant to her COVID-19 exposure. She attended a tourism industry conference in St. Thomas, USVI from June 1-3, 2024, involving close contact with other hospitality professionals. Prior to that, she vacationed in San Juan, Puerto Rico from May 15-20, 2024, engaging in various tourist activities. In mid-April (April 10-13, 2024), she traveled to Miami, Florida for a marketing conference where she presented and networked. All trips involved potential exposure to diverse groups in enclosed spaces (conferences, accommodations) and public transportation (ferry, airplanes), which could have increased risk of COVID-19 transmission. Patient denies any known direct contact with confirmed COVID-19 cases during these travels, but acknowledges the possibility of exposure given the nature of her activities and locations visited.

Encounter_Details.Discharge Disposition: Discharged to home or self care (routine discharge)

Encounter_Type_Entries.Description: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 screening (procedure)

Practitioner_Documents.Reason for Visit: Mild fever, cough, and fatigue for 2-3 days
Practitioner_Documents.Past Medical History: Patient has a history of seasonal allergies and occasional migraines. No history of chronic respiratory conditions or other significant medical issues. Last physical exam was 8 months ago, with normal results. Family history is notable for hypertension in both parents and type 2 diabetes in her father. Patient maintains a healthy weight and exercises regularly.
Practitioner_Documents.Review of Systems:
General: Reports fatigue and mild fever. No chills, night sweats, or unexplained weight changes.
Respiratory: Dry cough present. No shortness of breath, wheezing, or chest pain.
ENT: Mild sore throat. No nasal congestion or runny nose. No changes in taste or smell.
Cardiovascular: No palpitations, chest pain, or edema.
Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain.
Musculoskeletal: Mild body aches. No joint pain or swelling.
Neurological: Reports a mild headache. No dizziness, confusion, or loss of consciousness.
Psychiatric: Mood stable. No anxiety or depression noted.
Skin: No rashes or unusual skin changes.
Endocrine: No polyuria, polydipsia, or heat/cold intolerance.
Hematologic: No easy bruising or bleeding.
Allergic/Immunologic: No recent allergic reactions or new environmental exposures.
Practitioner_Documents.History of Present Illness: Aisha Gumbs, a 35-year-old Black female from Christiansted, USVI, presents with a 2-3 day history of mild fever, dry cough, and fatigue. Symptoms began gradually, with fatigue and a low-grade fever first noted on June 12, 2024. A dry cough developed the following day, along with a mild sore throat and headache. Patient reports a maximum temperature of 37.8°C (100°F) at home. She denies shortness of breath, loss of taste or smell, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Patient has been managing symptoms with over-the-counter acetaminophen and rest. She reports recent travel, including a business trip to St. Thomas, USVI (June 1-3), a vacation in San Juan, Puerto Rico (May 15-20), and a conference in Miami, Florida (April 10-13). No known direct contact with confirmed COVID-19 cases, but acknowledges potential exposure during travel. Patient is fully vaccinated against COVID-19 but has not received a booster in the past year. She works as a Senior Marketing Manager at a local resort and has been working from home since symptom onset.
Practitioner_Documents.Plan of Treatment:
1. COVID-19 Testing: Performed rapid antigen test in office, which returned positive. PCR test ordered for confirmation.
2. Home Isolation: Advised patient to isolate at home for at least 5 days from symptom onset, and to continue isolation until fever-free for 24 hours without fever-reducing medication.
3. Symptom Management: Continue acetaminophen as needed for fever and discomfort. Recommended increased fluid intake and rest.
4. Monitoring: Patient instructed to monitor symptoms closely. Advised to seek immediate medical attention if experiencing shortness of breath, persistent chest pain, confusion, or bluish lips or face.
5. Follow-up: Telehealth appointment scheduled for 3 days from now to assess symptom progression and recovery.
6. Work: Provided work excuse note for 5 days, with possible extension based on symptom resolution.
7. Close Contacts: Advised patient to inform close contacts of potential exposure.
8. Supportive Care: Recommended use of throat lozenges for sore throat and honey for cough if desired.
9. Education: Provided patient education on COVID-19, including transmission, typical course, and when to seek emergency care.
10. Vaccination: Discussed importance of staying up-to-date with COVID-19 vaccinations. Will reassess eligibility for booster dose after recovery.
11. Return Precautions: Instructed patient to return or seek emergency care if symptoms worsen, particularly if experiencing difficulty breathing.
Practitioner_Documents.Vaccine Credential Patient Assertion: Patient reports receiving initial COVID-19 vaccination series (Pfizer-BioNTech) in April 2021. Received one booster dose in January 2023. Unable to provide exact dates or lot numbers. No adverse reactions reported from previous vaccinations.

Procedure_Entries.Procedure Description: Infectious agent antigen detection by immunoassay technique, (eg, enzyme immunoassay [EIA], enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay [ELISA], fluorescence immunoassay [FIA], immunochemiluminometric assay [IMCA]) qualitative or semiquantitative; severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (eg, SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2 [COVID-19])
Procedure_Entries.Details: Rapid antigen test for SARS-CoV-2 performed in office

Procedure_Entries.Details: COVID-19 booster vaccination planned after recovery, pending eligibility assessment

Procedure_Entries.Procedure Description: Telephone evaluation and management service by a physician or other qualified health care professional who may report evaluation and management services provided to an established patient, parent, or guardian not originating from a related E/M service provided within the previous 7 days nor leading to an E/M service or procedure within the next 24 hours or soonest available appointment; 11-20 minutes of medical discussion
Procedure_Entries.Details: Telehealth follow-up appointment scheduled to assess symptom progression and recovery

Case_Summary.Summary: This is a fictional representation of healthcare data intended for interoperability testing and solution development. The data are entirely fictitious and do not represent a real person or a real clinical scenario. Aisha Gumbs, a 35-year-old Black female from Christiansted, USVI, presented with mild COVID-19 symptoms on June 14, 2024. She reported fever, cough, and fatigue starting June 12, following recent travel. A rapid antigen test and PCR confirmed COVID-19. She was prescribed home isolation, symptom management with OTC medications, and close monitoring. A telehealth follow-up was scheduled. Her prognosis was excellent, with full recovery expected through rest and OTC medications.
